categories.info:
According to the commission, about 80% of people will likely vote absentee in this election, a giant leap from the normal 6% that utilizes the process during typical years.

Here's what you need to know about early in-person voting or voting by mail with an absentee ballot.

questions.categoryInfo:
According to the commission, about 80% of people will likely vote absentee in this election, a giant leap from the normal 6% that utilizes the process during typical years.

Here's what you need to know about early in-person voting or voting by mail with an absentee ballot.
questions.question: What are the deadlines for voting absentee?
questions.answer:
Clerks started mailing absentee ballots to voters who had requested them in mid-September. They'll continue to send them out as they receive more requests.

These are the key dates for mail-in absentee ballots for the 2020 general election:

  • Oct. 27: As stated on the Wisconsin Elections Commission website, this is the "practical deadline for voters to return their mail absentee ballots."

    "The US Postal Service recommends allowing one week for your completed ballot to be delivered. After this date, voters should find other options for returning their absentee ballot, which include delivering it to their municipal clerk’s office or a secure drop box if one is provided by their clerk."

  • Oct. 29: This is the legal deadline for most voters to request an absentee ballot by mail, but it is later than recommended for mailing ballots back to the clerk.

  • Nov. 3: Election Day, and the deadline for absentee ballots to be back to clerks.

  • Dates could change: A federal judge has ruled clerks can count ballots that arrive between Nov. 4 and Nov. 9 if they are postmarked on Nov. 3 or earlier. However, he has suspended that ruling while it is on appeal, and his ruling is not in effect at this time.

The City of Milwaukee will not allow absentee ballots to be returned to polling places on Election Day. Instead, voters should use the secure drop boxes or return their ballots to Central Count, 501 W. Michigan St., by 8 p.m.
questions.linkOne: Answers to other questions about voting absentee in Wisconsin

questions.question: I applied for an absentee ballot but never recieved it. What now?
questions.answer:
First check your status on myvote.wi.gov and go to the "Track my ballot" section. Look up your name and click the button on the left that says "View my request" and check the status of your absentee ballot.

You can also contact your municipal clerk to find out more.

If you haven't filled out and sent your absentee ballot by Oct. 27 — the Elections Commission's "practical deadline for voters to return their mail absentee ballots" in order to be mailed in on time for Election Day — your best option will be to go to an early voting location before Nov. 1, when early voting locations close, or head to the polls on Nov. 3.

According to the Wisconsin Elections Commission website: "If you didn’t get your ballot, you can vote in person at your polling place."

questions.question: Can I vote early without using the mail?
questions.answer:
All registered voters can check their voting record at myvote.wi.goven-us/MyVoterInfo

Intelligent mail bar codes will be used for ballots sent out for the November election, meaning that clerks will be able to track ballots on every step of their journey. Voters will see a condensed version of the travel history of their ballot on the myvote.wi.gov website, showing when their ballot is sent out, the anticipated delivery date and when it is received by the clerk when completed. The intelligent mail system will notify clerks if there are issues with ballots not being sent or ballots going missing in the mail. Guidance is also being developed for canceling and reissuing ballots when voters have problems with the mail.

questions.question: What kind of pen/pencil should i use to fill out my ballot?
questions.answer:
A black ballpoint pen is the best way to fill out your ballot, said Reid Magney, the public information officer for the Elections Commission. A blue pen can be used, but isn't recommended. Red, green or yellow shouldn't be used, and neither should permanent markers or highlighters because they can bleed through the paper.

If there's a problem with what a ballot is marked with, two poll workers would have to re-mark a new ballot, and that takes time when the ballots are being processed on Election Day.

questions.question: What does my ballot need before I send it back?
questions.answer:
After filling out an absentee ballot, you'll need to seal it in the envelope and sign the front. The envelope also requires a signature from a witness who watched you fill out the ballot. The witness must sign the envelope and provide their full address in order for the ballot to be counted.

According to the Elections Commission, the witness who signs your ballot must be a U.S. citizen age 18 or older. Your witness can be your friend, a spouse, a family member, a neighbor or anyone else who is able to watch you fill out your ballot and put it in the envelope. Candidates on the ballot are the only people who are not able to be witnesses.

questions.question: Where can I drop off my completed ballot?
questions.answer:
Numerous communities have installed absentee ballot drop boxes. The decision to have drop boxes is made by local officials.

Milwaukee has been working to avoid a replay of April's election, when masked voters waited in long lines in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic to cast their ballots on election day and technical issues marred production of absentee ballots.

Milwaukee has installed 15 absentee ballot drop boxes ahead of November's presidential election.

The 24-hour drop boxes are available outside City Hall, at the city's 13 neighborhood Milwaukee Public Library branches and at the Milwaukee Election Commission's warehouse at 1901 S. Kinnickinnic Ave. Here's the full list.

The drop boxes will be available until 8 p.m. on Nov. 3, when the polls close. The ballots will be collected each day by staff of the Election Commission, and the frequency of collection will increase closer to the election.

The boxes are under 24-hour video surveillance and have seals to ensure they haven't been opened in an unauthorized manner.
questions.linkOne: Milwaukee gears up for historic election in which up to 70% of voters may not cast a ballot at polls on Nov. 3

questions.question: Is there a way to track my ballot?
questions.answer:
All registered voters can check their voting record at myvote.wi.goven-us/MyVoterInfo

Intelligent mail bar codes will be used for ballots sent out for the November election, meaning that clerks will be able to track ballots on every step of their journey. Voters will see a condensed version of the travel history of their ballot on the MyVote.wi.gov website, showing when their ballot is sent out, the anticipated delivery date and when it is received by the clerk when completed. The intelligent mail system will notify clerks if there are issues with ballots not being sent or ballots going missing in the mail. Guidance is also being developed for canceling and reissuing ballots when voters have problems with the mail.

questions.question: I requested a ballot but decided I wanted to vote in person. What should I do?
questions.answer:
If a voter requests a ballot, fills it out and sends it back, that is the vote that will be counted. Voters cannot request another ballot in person at a polling place.

If a voter requests an absentee ballot but decides they would rather cast their vote in person, poll workers will be able to cancel that absentee ballot.

If an issue is detected with the mailing process, like a ballot sitting in a sorting center for too long, the absentee ballot can be canceled and reissued.

categories.info: Only U.S. citizens are allowed to vote in Wisconsin. You can register at your local municipal clerk's office until the close of business the Friday before the election. Or you can register at the polling place on Election Day. You can check your registration status at the My Vote Wisconsin website.

questions.categoryInfo: Only U.S. citizens are allowed to vote in Wisconsin. You can register at your local municipal clerk's office until the close of business the Friday before the election. Or you can register at the polling place on Election Day. You can check your registration status at the My Vote Wisconsin website.
questions.question: How will COVID-19 impact Nov. 3?
questions.answer:
Wisconsin's April election for a seat on the state Supreme Court, the presidential primary and a host of local offices put a global spotlight on the state for holding an election in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic.

Wisconsin is now trying to remedy a host of difficulties it faced during the primary to prepare for the November presidential election.

Milwaukee and Green Bay had a dearth of polling locations in April but plan to have far more available in November. Election officials have put in place plans to frequently clean voting machines and will be enforcing social distancing at the polls. They are also attempting to hire more poll workers, but may be using plainclothes National Guard members to help them at the polls, as they have during other elections this year.

Officials are encouraging voters to wear masks, but not requiring them.

questions.question: When are polls open?
questions.answer:
Early voting hours vary by community.

On Nov. 3, the polls are open statewide from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m.

As long as people are in line by 8 p.m., they will be allowed to vote.

questions.question: What if I don't have a driver's license? What kind of ID works?
questions.answer:
Voters need to show an acceptable photo ID to vote at a polling place. Among the photo IDs acceptable for voting are:

  • Wisconsin Department of Transportation-issued driver's license
  • Wisconsin DOT-issued identification card
  • U.S. passport
  • Military ID card issued by a U.S. uniformed service
  • Veteran's photo ID card issued by the Veterans Health Administration of the federal Department of Veterans Affairs
  • ID card issued by a federally recognized Indian tribe in Wisconsin.
  • Some forms of college IDs can also be used.

    The address on your ID doesn't have to match your current address, and some types of IDs can be used even if they have recently expired.

    More information on the photo ID requirement is available at bringitwisconsin.com.
questions.linkTwo: Video: Learn how to register and vote in Wisconsin in less than 60 seconds

questions.question: How do I find my voting location?
questions.answer:
Your assigned polling place is based on where you live. You can find your polling place by entering your address at myvote.wi.gov.

If you have moved more than 10 days before Nov. 3: You must vote at the polling place for your new address if you have lived there for at least 10 days, and you will have to register to vote.

If you have moved fewer than 10 days before Nov. 3: You must vote from your prior address.

questions.question: How many polling locations are open in Milwaukee this time?
questions.answer: Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, many communities limited the number of in-person polling locations this spring. In Milwaukee's April election, there were five polling locations. For the August primary, the city opened 168 locations, or about 95% of the city's usual polling locations. For Nov. 3 general election, all normal locations are expected to be open.
questions.linkOne: What we know about why Milwaukee only had 5 voting sites for the April primary election

categories.info: Key players competing for votes across the state.

questions.categoryInfo: Key players competing for votes across the state.
questions.question: How are Donald Trump and Joe Biden faring in Wisconsin?
questions.answer:
Trump won Wisconsin in 2016 by less than 1%.

In a poll released Sept. 9 by the Marquette University Law School, Biden had 47% and Trump had 43%.

questions.question: What state races should I be paying attention to?
questions.answer:
All eyes are on the presidential race this year.

Wisconsin does not have a race for U.S. senator, governor or other statewide office this fall. All eight seats in Congress are up this fall, as are all 99 seats in the state Assembly and 16 of the 33 seats in the state Senate.

categories.info: There's a chance we may not know who the winner is the night of Nov. 3. With numerous states allowing mail-in voting, and many voters taking advantage of that process due to COVID-19 precautions, the likelihood that absentee ballots will be counted in time for live precinct results is low.

questions.categoryInfo: There's a chance we may not know who the winner is the night of Nov. 3. With numerous states allowing mail-in voting, and many voters taking advantage of that process due to COVID-19 precautions, the likelihood that absentee ballots will be counted in time for live precinct results is low.
questions.question: Where are Wisconsin's live results?
questions.answer:
Please check back on Nov.3 for a live results page link.*

*Please be aware that due to the vast number of voters using absentee and early voting methods this year, live results will likely be inconclusive on election night. Some absentee ballots may not be counted until Nov. 4 or later. A federal judge has ruled clerks can count ballots that arrive between Nov. 4 and Nov. 9 if they are postmarked on Nov. 3 or earlier. However, he has suspended that ruling while it is on appeal, and his ruling is not in effect at this time.

questions.question: When are absentee ballots and early in-person votes counted?
questions.answer:
Absentee ballots — including those cast at early-voting locations — are checked into a poll book when recieved, but poll workers can't open and feed them into counting machines until polls open on Nov. 3.

Counting those ballots takes much longer than votes cast on Election Day.

Clerks from both parties for years have pushed for a change in state law that would allow them to start counting at least some absentee ballots before Election Day.

"We are not anticipating that we will be done and have results right at 9 p.m. or 10 p.m. but I’m hopeful that by the time the sun comes up on Nov. 4th we will be finished and have election results," Claire Woodall-Vogg, the executive director of the Milwaukee Election Commission, said.

Without Milwaukee's full results, it likely won't be known whether Republican President Donald Trump or Democrat Joe Biden won the state.

A court decision could also delay the results for at least a week depending on the outcome of an appeal. A federal judge ruled clerks can count ballots that arrive between Nov. 4 and Nov. 9 if they are postmarked on Nov. 3 or earlier. However, he has suspended that ruling while it is on appeal, and his ruling is not in effect at this time.
